displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -but the Aliguard’s okay right? Patient: Aliguard is okay. I'm tired. Yeah, but it doesn’t totally destabilize my life. Doctor: Right, right. I think when you get off the Xtandi, you're actually gonna feel a little bit better. Because you know, at four pills a day does weigh on you. So I think that would be better. But I'm gonna talk to S____, our research nurse who's covering for M____ who's our regular research nurse. But S___ will come in here and will just go over and see how you feel about it. You know if you're interested, great. We'll move forward and do what we need to do. We have to check to make sure all these lovely things can stay on and if not, we do regular chemo. Family Member: Well, it makes me feel good is one big concern. I get is that if he starts getting so much bone loss he can't function and his quality of life and if you can zap areas at which I didn't know. Yeah, it makes me realize hey he can have a quality of life. Doctor: Oh yeah that's number one. Family Member: There you go S___. Doctor: Living is very important but we can't do it with you laid up in bed doing nothing and just say well it's good we got the prostate cancer all taken care of. Family Member: Right that’s not good. Doctor: I say that all the time too. Patient: The one on my ribs doesn't bother me. Doctor: It doesn’t bother you. Patient: That doesn’t bother me. The one that frightens me is the one’s going up and down my spine.

Healthcare Professional: This is the one you take in the morning and at night. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So - that’s why I said if I give you the Percocet it’s going to lower your dose of OxyContin. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: But if that works for you I’m good with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If it doesn’t work we’ll have to go back to the other OxyContin. Patient: Original. Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because that’s what you asked for. Patient: Right.

Patient: We’ll reevaluate. We’ll take a look at it, you understand? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Maybe in October or December – Doctor: Okay. Patient: Of next year. Doctor: Mr. L_, I know from talking with you the last time. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You were not keen on getting cut open or getting your bowels or your pee’s re-routed. Patient: I’m really not. Doctor: I know you’re not. Patient: I mean, and they want me to put the bag on. Doctor: I know they do.

Patient: Yeah, who wants to Doctor: He was like well, um, I have a person here who claims to be your patient. I’m like I don’t know where here is, right, but his name is blah, blah, blah. So, the thing is that particular patient we’re always joking around so I’m like is this guy punking me at nine p.m. at night and I was about just this close to going nope, never heard of him, right, but somewhere in the recesses of my mind I’m like maybe this sounds more serious. I go yes and he goes okay, well, anyways we’re at the border patrol. Patient: Oh, wow. Doctor: He set off the sensors. They went on full lock down, like everything, Patient: Oh, geez Doctor: like guns drawn because they thought he was like transporting plutonium or something. Patient: Oh, my God! Wow Doctor: But I didn’t know it was my patient because rightly so they didn’t allow him to call from his cellphone. Patient: That makes sense. Doctor: So they had to call from the border. Oh, man! So then I was like oh, my gosh, then I was like well, how do I know you are who you say you are so I gave it right back to him and I go so, you know, what’s your phone number so just to be safe I called the guy back. I was like I don’t know who this person is, you know, it might be… Patient: Right, that’s a good point. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah and then, you know, there he was.

Patient: Let me say this here, Doc. Let me say this here. Everything that you tell me and you do – Doctor: Mm,hmm. Patient: she goes and she looks up everything Doctor: Perfect. Yes. Patient: You know I’m just surrounded with just good people taking good care. Doctor: People who care. Here’s what I said about the bike trip. It’s up to him really to be smart about it. You know I know he loves it and this is something he just has to work out by himself and also with you guys. There’s no real medical reason technically and it’s gonna take us a week or two to get that medicine, so there’s time. He says he’s not gonna stay down in F____. Family Member: It’s just what bothers me about it is the pain that sometimes he go through. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Sometimes the pain can be a ten and then sometimes the pain can be a four. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If he had a four, I’d be comfortable with him being on the bike – Doctor: Yeah, I know.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So he can let her – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: He can give her the password. The system doesn’t know who’s looking. You know, but it is his password. Family Member: Right. Okay. Doctor: Okay? But you need to be able to call her or talk to her or you have to sign forms out front to give me release. Okay? Family Member: Right. Doctor: But I also would prefer the two of you be the voice, you know. ‘Cuz for me to go over it four different times just because -- Family Member: Right. Doctor: Someone’s not able to get here makes it difficult. Family Member: Right. Patient: Well she has court today. Her ex-husband is –

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: but you really want to go for the home run. So we do not have a home run. We all know that by now. We have patients on this study where um they get the same drug you’ve got or the same dose – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - and their PSA drops by ninety-eight percent in the first two months. We’ve seen that. You’re not one of those guys. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We also have other people where the PSA continues to increase at the same pace or in some people it even speeds up. So you’re not in that category either. Then we have some people where the PSA you know slows down, they stay on the drug for anywhere between four to six months. It’s probably doing something, but it’s not know the desired effect or the absolute you know, perfect effect that we expected, so it’s sort of a middle ground, and yet it’s hard to justify you know to keep going if all you’re seeing is like a lukewarm type of response. Patient: Right, right, right. Doctor: So um I I think the time has come uh to uh stop this study and potentially switch gears. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um there’s two primary reasons for that. One is um PSA level has now increased by more than double - Patient: Yes. Doctor: - compared to the first one; call that the baseline number. So the trial was designed in such a way - because we don’t want to be giving people an experimental therapy and harming them by delaying improving therapy. So the trial was designed in such a way that it was built with a safety check. And the safety check is if the PSA goes up by twofold, then, in other words, a one hundred percent increase from baseline, then patient will come off study. So you have now crossed that threshold. Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Such as radiation instead of hormone therapy in order to delay you know the need for hormone therapy. And the other is to start the hormone therapy now and try to combine it with something that may make the hormone therapy work better and longer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: From what I’m hearing and reading between the lines, what I think I’m hearing is that you’d rather try at this point in time something that is a non-hormonal approach such as radiotherapy. And if that is the case, I think that we have an interesting study that I could talk to you about which is using what we call stereotactic radiotherapy. It’s also called CyberKnife because the company that makes the machine that delivers the radiation is called CyberKnife. It’s not a knife; it’s a misnomer. It’s not surgery – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But because the beam of radiation is so precise, it’s called a knife because it’s as precise as a surgeon’s knife. Um if you think that I’m misunderstanding and you really are more open to the hormone therapy option as well or instead of radiation and we also have a trial in that category which is trying to ask the question about whether all hormone therapy in conjunction with a new hormone therapy is better than just the old hormone therapy by itself, the conventional. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So I don’t really know where you’re at but I think I’m hearing that you may be interested in thinking about this radiation option first? Patient: Well as a Patient, you have a person that quote/unquote “has the cancer”. Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: My primary objective would be to get rid of it. Doctor: Uh hum.

Family Member 1: Let's go to the kitchen, not the bathroom. Patient: Yeah, I won't be doing that. Doctor: Yeah, I think it you know, it's always hard. Patient: I don’t want to get too much involved. Doctor: I mean, the easiest way to get Patient: I just won’t go there. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, good idea. Doctor: I just wont go there. Healthcare Professional: How old is she? Family Member 1: Yeah but the Mother is. Doctor: Yeah, but they’re always into things and we talked about this. Family Member 1: She’s not out of her first trimester. Yeah.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh and then they pretty much send you home. Um and they, they’ve been treating about every two months, so. Patient: So then you go back again? Doctor: Potentially, yeah. Patient: Potentially? Doctor: I know they’ve done uh I want to say up to four treatments I’ve seen at the most for every two months or so. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: They, they uh, I don’t think they’ve worked out totally the scheme of what’s the best way to do it, every two months at most it’s been. Each center does it slightly different. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh but that’s, that’s about what they do. Uh I’m not really sure because they haven’t seen profound bone marrow effects. One of the problems with radioactive things is you can get- Patient: Sure. Um hum. Doctor: Injury to the bone marrow. My experience with them is that particularly with patients who’ve had, not had a lot of chemotherapy, so not a lot of things to injure the bone marrow, they don’t seem to really have a problem with bone marrow toxicity from this study.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Not with Dr. S_. Patient: I’m not going to get more radi— Doctor: So, you don’t necessarily need to keep seeing him. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. Just Patient: I think that’s probably his standard of care that he has to follow up, but if you’re following up - Doctor: Well, I would keep the appointment with him in January. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, maybe after that I could see you in April and if it turns out in January, your PSA has, you know, gone - instead of continuing to go south, it’s gone north, or we may, we may need to switch treatments whatever, then I would, I would maybe see you sooner to discuss that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, I, why don’t I - I’m going to make the appointment, I think, part of this appointment this January and, uh, I’m not sure if he’s doing the six-month injection, but, um, I’ll make an appointment for, it’s says April sixteenth. I’ll just make it April seventeenth which is a Tuesday. And, you don’t have to see him; you just see me.

Patient: Okay. Family Member: It’s almost every three weeks. Patient: Yeah. I don’t know if, yeah, if we screw up. Family Member: These are all the dates on all the different things he has to work through for cataract surgery. Doctor: Yeah. These are just the follow-ups. One week, one day, two weeks, and four weeks. Okay. That’s not a big deal. All uh. And those days are changeable. I mean, we can do Monday versus another. Family Member: Sure. Um hum. We can put off the cataract surgery, too. Doctor: Yeah. If he had to. Family Member: But it’s hard to get. Doctor: But for now let’s keep it. Family Member: That’s what I think. We’ve waited a long time. Doctor: Don’t, don’t change anything until we see what the dates fall out to be. Family Member: Fine. Yeah.

Family Member: Yeah so we’d be on two clinical trials? Doctor: Well this one you’ll just be in follow-up. You won’t be actively on this particular one. Family Member: So the Xtandi… Doctor: So you’ll be off active treatment from our current clinical trial because you’ve progressed technically. Patient: So I wouldn’t be part of that clinical trial? Doctor: You’d still be part of it for follow-up reasons but not actively on. So you wouldn’t get the Xtandi from this particular clinical trial Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: anymore. Which… Patient: Just a second, even with the BET1? Doctor: No. For the BET1 that study will then kick in you’ll be registered to that study and they will give you from that study they will give you the Xtandi and the BET medication. Patient: Because ten thousand dollars a month is not something… Doctor: Well that’s okay. We can find ways around it and getting it covered if we need to. But chances are if you were to go on standard treatment, then yeah we’d have to wait and see what your insurance pays. Sorry about that. Family Member: That’s okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.::: strongly disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Other: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Other

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Oh, okay. Alright. Family Member: If it is, they take it to next level. Doctor: So, again, theoretically, if you stayed on treatment and then three months from now, he clearly showed a progression of disease then, there might be a window when the slot would be available. Patient: Okay. So, if I stay on this for three months, it’s most likely that, uh, let’s say it’s group two (for sake of argument) Doctor: Correct. For the current cohort, uh, oh, one slot left. Patient: One slot. Okay. So, if it is filled by the end of next week. Let’s say I, uh, decide not to, uh, take it. Um. Doctor: That person has to be on treatment for a month. And then they -- Patient: December. Doctor: Then they can decide that there’s now three more spots, you know. Patient: It would be six more slots in group three. It says, “Six cohorts groups of up to six subjects.” Doctor: Right. So, they do three. And if any of them have a bad side effect, they have three more. Patient: Oh.

Patient: and you think what is he doing. And he’s visualizing what he’s going to do. And he said it’s important to visualize that you succeed Doctor: Correct. Patient: because he said if you visualize you’re going to go off the ramp; he said you’re going to go off the ramp. Patient: That was a while ago. Doctor: That was a long time ago, like ABC or something, “Wide World of Sports.” Patient: Yeah, it was ABC, yeah. Doctor: Yeah, GOSH, thanks for the flash back. Patient: Oh yeah. Doctor: I like stay positive. But you know me to be positive anyway. Patient: So we might want to do a blood test today? Doctor: Yeah, just to get everything on the record here because the last one was obviously August. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Seventeen.
